text: TITLE: TWO DAYS AGO. Snowstorm. A single man in a rowboat the STRANGER -- forges through the icy waters toward the coast. It’s hard to say how old he is -- 20s, 40s? -- bec he’s so filthy and red-eyed and yet so fiercely driven. In shadows behind him stands the eerie, forbidding SHIP w brought him this far. Hitting the edge of the ice, the Stranger clambers out of his boat and trudges inland, smi thinly as he sees the boat drift away, no use to him anym TITLES ROLL as we follow the Stranger through the wide, e twilight of the Alaskan wilderness -- blasted by the wind persevering, too yearning and wild-eyed to slow down -- As he crests a small ridge of ice, we see a clutch of lig shimmering in the distance: BARROW, ALASKA. An Arctic out of a town, an oil and mining outpost ringed with derricks tundra. The Stranger grins as he sees Barrow twinkling through the snowstorm, and presses onward AS TITLES END -

TITLE: TONIGHT. A MAN stands, back to the setting sun, hi face cloaked in shadows -- until he turns thoughtfully, t light gradually revealing a weathered and soulful gaze. H SHERIFF EBEN OLESON, early 30s --
Strange. He faces BILLY KITKA, earnest, 40s, wearing a deputy’s ba and shining a flashlight into a snowbank west of Barrow -
Ain’t it? Who’d do a thing like this? THEIR POV: a smoldering, eerie hole in the snow -- filled
Eben kneels down to examine the firepit, baffled -- BILLY (cont'd) Someone got a little upset about roaming charges?
Stealing satellite phones’d make sense, you could hock them, maybe run up charges on someone’s account. But burning them? +e
Kids? Pulling some prank?

There’d be a message. “Fuck you” to their parents or the world or whoever. Eben walks up toward the summit, thoughtfully -- EBEN (cont'd) Best place to solve this is the Diner, Billy. Get people talking, they’1l gossip and figure it out for us. Billy watches as Eben keeps hiking toward the crest --
The last golden arc of the sun gleams, silhouetting Eben, Billy comes to join him.
I remember I brought Peggy here on our first date.
We all did. Not Peggy, I mean, just --
(light chuckle) I gotcha. C’mon, let’s do the sign -- (studying his friend) You okay? Eben stares out at the sun quietly, wistfully --

Yeah, I only -- (a beat) Last sunset for a month, some years it’s easier to take, y’know? Eben turns, not ready to say more, and Billy knows better to ask. Shoving his feelings down deep, Eben hikes back toward the 4x4 waiting at the bottom of the slope --
The sun’s down, but light filters through approaching nig The 4x4 comes to a stop beside a bright, good-natured sig from a Tourism Bureau with a sense of humor:

“WELCOME TO BARROW, ALASKA -- TOP OF THE WORLD! POPULATIO 563 -- WARNING! DANGER! POLAR BEARS!” Billy jumps from the 4x4 to the “WELCOME TO BARROW” sign, pulling out some metal tags. Eben calls from the car --
Nobody’s gonna see that sign for the next thirty days --
It’s a tradition! Billy hangs the tags “152” over the “563,” changing the population for the winter. OVER THIS, THE SOUND OF DOGS

Elongating shadows from the fleeting amber daylight. The residential side of Barrow. Homes are built on stilts to avoid the stresses of ice and critters in their foundatio All the homes have crawlspaces underneath, of varying siz FOUR HUSKIES ARE BARKING from behind the fence of the RII residence -- sled dogs deeply unhappy about something -- A SHADOW passes across the screen -- the dogs follow the shadow angrily -- until suddenly there is a GLEAMING FLAS HISS OF A BLADE -- the SICKENING SLICE OF A KNIFE INTO FL and the barks are replaced by horrifying WHINES OF PAIN. EXT. BARROW CITY LIMITS/EBEN’S 4X4 - DUSK 5A At the edge of town, Eben and Billy pull over beside a HU SNOWPLOW swerved crookedly onto the shoulder. The back is covered with a tarp; a stream of oil drips from the truck Working under the open hood is BEAU BROWER, late 50s, thi bearded, an ox of a man with the social skills to match.
Little problem?
(not a glance up) Nothin’ I can’t handle my own fuckin’ self. Eben gets out of his 4x4, circles the vehicle, pulls a le GAS CAN from under the tarp.
This for generators?
Mostly.
I can’t have it leaking all over the roads, Beau. I’1l have to cite you for that. He pulls out a citation book, scribbles away as Beau rant

You don’t HAVETA cite me. You don’t HAVETA do anything. That’s why we live up here, innit? So we gotta little freedom? Why don’t you run Billy on home so he can cuddle with that cute wifey of his? One of us oughta get laid tonight, at least -- Eben rips a ticket blithely, tucks it in Beau’s parka --
Happy motoring.
I’ll add this to my collection. Eben climbs back in the 4x4 and starts the engine --
Beau’s not so bad. Why do you bother writing him up?
He lives all by himself in that cabin on the south ridge, y'know? A little citation now and then reminds Beau he’s part of this town.
He’s right, though --
About what?
You should drop me at home. The wife always likes the first night of the Dark -- Eben gently smirks as the WALKIE-TALKIE BLARES with the V of his elderly dispatcher, HELEN --
Eben, come in, Eben --
Roger, Helen --
You better get over to John Riis’s -- something bad’s happened to his dogs -- Eben glances at Billy, puzzled and concerned: what the he
TOM MELANSON, teens, sturdy, kisses his GIRLFRIEND goodby

See you in the light, baby -- I’1l be good while you’re gone, I promise -- TRUCK PAST Tom and his girlfriend through the town’s main drag, still warm in the ebbing light of magic hour. Simpl white lights, all the town can afford, spark to life, giv Barrow a naive romance. TOWNSFOLK mill about, celebrating like it’s New Year's Eve. HONKING horns, hugging and kiss DOUG HERTZ, late 30s, brawny and well fed, kisses HIS WIF

-- ‘sokay, sweetie, I know you can’t take a month with no sun -- I promise I won’t live on Oreos and Snapple -- KIRSTEN TOOMEY, lean, 20, hands suitcases to HER FATHER P 40s, as he loads up his car for the airport --
-- wish you’d come with me, Kirsten. I hate this place in December. Nothing here but twenty-eight miles of road, and all of them dead-end.
(hugs him goodbye) I’m gonna get all caught up, Dad, the taxes, January’s orders, don’t worry! Have fun in Seattle!

CHARLIE KELSO, 40s, HAMMERS the last planks to board up h HOUSE, a successful oil worker’s home with an ornamental of glass bricks in the facade. An impatient MRS. KELSO AN THEIR TWO SONS load luggage into their Range Rover.
Charlie, do you want to make it to Maui or not? Her voice is such that Charlie’s not altogether sure abou Maui, but he finishes hammering nonetheless --

STELLA OLESON -- 20s, hardy, attractive, in the jacket of Alaska State Fire Marshal’s office -- works under deadlin inspect foam firefighting tanks housed outside the genera store. Walking by with a trashbin is store proprietor ADA COLLETTA, 30s, genial and sturdy --
Kinda put this off till the last minute, didja?
A lot of small towns in this state -- my boss wants all their gear inspected and certified by the 31st.

And I notice you saved Barrow for last -- sure you don’t wanna stay? Jeannie and I were kinda hoping you and Eben -- Stella shakes her head patiently: it’s not happening. She checks forms on her clipboard, closes it, heads for her 4

Thanks a ton. Gotta make the plane -- She starts up her engine as Adam sighs -- shame to see a like this alone -- EXT./INT. BARROW CITY LIMITS/STELLA’S 4X4 - DUSK 6C Stella's driving, hellbent for the airport. Coming from t left at a desolate intersection is a large DITCH DRILLER enormous RUMBLING truck with treads instead of tires, and maneuverable ROARING CHAINSAW mounted on its nose. The di driller SHOULD stop at a STOP SIGN -- But to Stella’s shock, the ditch driller DOESN’T stop, imbedding its chainsaw in one of Stella’s FRONT TIRES and fishtailing Stella's 4x4 to a full stop -- Stella emerges from her 4x4, livid --
Goddamn it, Malekai! Don’t you know what a stop sign means? Climbing out of the cab is MALEKAI HAMM, 20, abashed --

I’m sorry, Stella, the brakes jammed -- Mute with anger, Stella inspects both her own useless veh and the ditch driller -- MALEKAI (cont'd) Eben wanted this back from the airport before the storm hits, I was just trying to -- Stella doesn’t have time for Malekai’s sputtering guilt; pops the trunk on her 4x4 and pulls out her carryon bag, looking at the snowy, isolated expanse around them --
Who’s gonna run me to the airport?
Wouldn’t Eben -- ? Stella sighs deeply; of course Eben would, but --
I just popped into town for work, I didn’t want things to get messy --
My mom could bring the towtruck -- but y'know she doesn’t move so fast --

Thanks, Malekai -- For nothing. Stella gives up and pulls out her cellphone EXT. STREETS/EBEN’S 4X4 - DUSK 7 Eben’s dropping Billy off, when his CELLPHONE RINGS. He s “STELLA” on the display, CLICKS ON WARILY --
It’s me. Billy can tell who it is from Eben’s tone, lingers in the door of the 4x4 to eavesdrop, until Eben shoos him off --
EXT. BARROW CITY LIMITS —- DUSK - RESUME 7A Stella, anxious next to a sheepish Malekai, not looking forward to this call --
Surprise. I need a ride to the airport.
Wait -- what? You're in town -- ? And you didn’t want to talk -- ?

(not harsh, just honest) What about? Look, I had Fire Marshal work here, now I’m stuck at Ransom and 355, gotta get back to Anchorage before the airport closes. You want to talk, we can do it on the drive -- EXT. STREETS/EBEN’S 4X4 -— DUSK -— RESUME 7B Maybe Eben doesn’t want to talk if this is how she’s gonn He covers the cellphone, checks his watch. Opening his do he YELLS DOWN THE STREET to the departing Billy --

HEY, BILLY! Stella’s at Ransom and 355, can you get her to a plane? Billy signals thumbs up, hikes off quickly, as Eben calml gets back on the cell -- EBEN (cont'd) Listen, John Riis needs my help with something, so Billy’s on his way. You let me know if a day comes when you DO wanna talk. EXT. BARROW CITY LIMITS - DUSK - SOME MOMENTS LATER 7c Stella examines the damage to her rental car -- not pleas She checks her watch. Even less pleased. Where is Billy? Malekai whines a bit ON HIS CELLPHONE --
-- yeah, Mom, Stella asked the same thing, could you just give me a tow?

Stella glances at the damaged car again, decides to take look at the ditch driller while Malekai haplessly loads a his junk out of the vehicle. She kneels by the tires, inspects the brakes -- and frowns --
Your limo’s here, Ms. Oleson -- ! Stella jumps up thankfully, grabs her carryon and boards Billy’s 4x4 as they talk --
You’1l be okay, Malekai -- (Malekai waves; to Billy) Where’ve you been?!
The car keys weren’t where I thought, and then I was like, wait, Rogers and 355, or Ransom? And then when I --
Never mind, let’s go -- EXT./INT. AIRPORT ROAD/BILLY’S 4X4 - NIGHT 7D Fully dark now. Stella checks her watch, practically writ with anxiousness --
You wanna know how Eben’s been doin’?
(a beat) You're gonna tell me whether I ask you or not, right? (Billy smiles lopsidedly) Just drive, okay?
Three oil workers, 20s, wobble past the PIPELINE. AARON ( half-empty Jack Daniels) and GABE eye DENISE hopefully; w she’s no starlet, to them she’s Catherine Zeta-Jones --
Look, my landlady doesn’t want pipeline workers keepin’ her up --
Denise is right, let’s head over to my place --
(playfully) Neither of you are getting me alone --
Then we’ll share! Right? None of us have to be greedy -- They all laugh, none of them sure where this might be hea but willing to see -- as Eben pulls up beside them.
Hey, Aaron -- you know there’s no drinking till the sun’s back up. They shift, embarrassed to be busted, as Gabe takes the b from Aaron and hands it to Eben --
We don’t need it, Eben. We can get drunk on Denise’s beauty and charm.
(laughing) I may throw up.
I won’t write you guys up tonight -- just don’t give me another reason till New Year’s, okay?
Yes sir -- we’ll be good -- The party walks away with Denise laughing --
EXT./INT. AIRPORT ROAD/BILLY’S 4X4 - NIGHT 11 Stella stares crestfallen at a SINGLE JET, capacity 120,
No, no, no, no -- }
(sympathetic) There’1l be someone you can bunk with for the month --
Don’t start, okay?
+e
No, I meant Lucy, or Denise, or hey, Peggy and me could even move the girls into one room and you --
I can’t stay here! I’ve got bills to put in the mail -- my plants’1l die!

Well, you can call somebody from our place to handle some o’ that, cantcha? You gotta know someone in Anchorage who can help? (off Stella, not happy) C’mon, it’ll work out. Course, the price of rent at my place might be explaining to me and Peggy what the heck’s wrong with you and Eben --
Not enough time this century to cover that, Billy --
Parties are over now, the streets quiet. STEAM still rise from the snow where Riis’s dogs died. JOHN RIIS, 40s, and wife ALLY, 30s, wiry and athletic, mourn with Eben.
What sick jerk would DO this?
Every kennel -- every dog we had.
Fight with anybody lately, John?
(shaking his head) Somebody always freaks out a little once the sun’s gone, but it usually takes two or three weeks.
I’ll kill them. I’11 kill them.  15 12.

(examining the scene) This wasn’t done long enough ago that you could get to the airport after. Whoever did this -- is still in town. OFF Eben, troubled -- INT. SHERIFF’S STATION - NIGHT 15 JAKE, 15, plays Risk against himself, moving from one sid the board to the other. Bright, pale, he’s like the love child of David Byrne and Elvis Costello. As he plays --

It'd be easier if you played, Helen -- Across the room, HELEN, late 60s, sits at the radio conso She doesn’t like you to know that she’s fighting cancer; positive attitude is one of her weapons against it.
I don’t really care for games like that, if you want to know the truth. Don’t you learn a lot when you play against yourself?
Yeah, yeah, yeah. Playing yourself is the ultimate blahdy-blah-blah -- Helen nods toward the entering Eben, laboriously sheds hi winter gear --
Try your brother. Eben appraises the gameboard as he takes a blast from an albuterol INHALER -- something he only does among family
“The Classic Game of Global Domination.” I’m a little jammed today -- Helen hands Eben some reports --
While you were busy with John Riis? Carter and Wilson called about a vandalism problem at the Utilidor -- Eben sighs, laboriously puts everything back on --  16 17 13.
Damn. What the hell’s goin’ on? He heads out with a nod to Jake, instructions for Helen - EBEN (cont'd) Call Point Hope and Wainwright, see if they’re having any troubles --

THE UTILIDOR SEWAGE PLANT sits on the edge of town: a PUM HOUSE and TWO TOWERING STORAGE TANKS. From the pump house comes CARTER DAVIES, 50s, Santa Claus build, in a Tourism Bureau T-shirt depicting a license plate reading “ALASKA B4UDIE.” He calls to the burly JAYKO TWINS, PAUL AND XAVI (both 36), cleaning a large SEWAGE PIPE some distance awa
Guys, you can’t get that pipe fixed tonight. Seal it off from the town and come back tomorrow -- The twins nod and seal off the pipe; Eben walks from his

Lord, Carter. It’s gotta be ten below. WILSON BULOSAN joins Carter in the doorway, his down vest reading “POLAR TOURS.” Filipino, early 30s, normally gregarious but now troubled, he gestures inside --
You need to see this, Eben --

Eben follows Carter and Wilson through the pump house, wh Carter monitors the sewage system. His control panel is adorned with knickknacks and photos, especially a PHOTO o Carter with his WIFE AND FOUR KIDS. Eben examines it --
Can’t your wife send you a sweater or two? And bring the whole tribe back here while she’s at it.
(shrugs diffidently) They’11 come when they’re ready, I guess --  18 19 14.
(gentle advice) * A family oughta be together, Carter -- * Carter nods in quiet resignation, acknowledging his frien changing the subject -- *
So I’ve found all kindsa garbage here over the years. Blue jeans, bikes. Sometimes I can yank ‘em out before the Muffin Monster chews ‘em to shit --
The Muffin Monster?
My little nickname for it --

Eben, Carter and Wilson stand before a HIGH-TORQUE, FOUR- SHREDDER, a device that can literally turn steel drums in confetti. This is the Muffin Monster, where all the pipes lead, disposing of Barrow’s garbage and sewage. The razor edged shafts spin steadily. Carter pulls up a trashcan --

Saw Wilson’s logo, pulled this stuff out before it got totally shredded -- Wilson angrily shows Eben a pile of chewed-up debris -- s belts, fragments of passenger seats, dashboard controls - couple of which bear the “POLAR TOURS” logo -- *
You keep your copter under lock and key, don’t you, Wilson?
Yep, I put it in drydock when the tourists headed south. Haven’t looked at it for days.
(examines the damage) Could you fix it up if you needed to?  20 21 22 15.

Not without parts from Anchorage. This is my living, Eben. Why would someone rip the hell out of my bird? Wilson takes some of the debris and angrily tosses it int Muffin Monster -- which chews it all up with STARTLING SP

An impressive SATELLITE DISH TOWER at the north end of to Bristling with ANTENNAE AND CELL RECEIVERS. The product o big time oil money. The Trans-Alaska PIPELINE runs past t base of the tower, beyond the barbed fence -- It’s starting to SNOW, the white flecks swirling about in darkness. TRACK THROUGH THE SNOW, AROUND THE TOWER -- A DEAD-WHITE FACE FLASHES IN THE STORM -- and is gone bef we can be sure we saw it at all --
GUS LAMBERT, late 60s, portly, sits at a control panel, WHISTLES an old swing band tune to himself --

head_text.subj: UP THE TOP OF THE SCALE --

text: Gus stops; he’s never heard anything like that before. St he’d ignore it until THERE’S AN ELECTRONIC SIZZLE -- HALF DIALS ON THE CONTROL PANEL BLINK OUT. Gus grabs his parka buttons up, and heads for the door --

Snow falls. Gus opens the door, walks out into the dark, shivering as his breath clouds around him. Behind him: TH CRUNCH OF A FOOTFALL IN SNOW. He whirls, shining his flashlight everywhere in the eerie silence, but sees noth Gus pushes forward into the darkness, as a SHAPE FLASHES BEHIND HIM, unseen by us -- he spins again as there’s ANO CRUNCH in the snow. He exploring for the source of the so but there’s still nothing. He’s tensing, realizing he doe want to be out here, heading back for the building -- When he comes across several lines of FOOTPRINTS crossing path back to the dish tower -- Quivering now, following the footprints with his flashlig Gus comes across a pair of GLEAMING BLACK EYES sizing him in the darkness --  23 24 25 16. Then they’re gone. He sweeps the beam urgently like a searchlight -- when a SHADOW CROSSES THE BEAM -- MUCH CLO TO HIM THIS TIME -- AND THEN IT’S GONE. Gus works to catch his breath -- what the hell is going o here? Then from right over his shoulder, A LOW GUTTERAL
Gus drops the flashlight and the beam shines into his terrified face. He’s surrounded by a GROUP OF SHADOWS, figures that loom menacingly toward him --

Who -- who are you people -- ?! WHOOOOM -- A SHADOW RIPS A TALONED HAND ACROSS GUS’ NECK Blood arcs through the darkness as Gus staggers backward and ONE OF THE SHADOWS LUNGES AT GUS. THERE IS A COARSE, SAWING SOUND as Gus’s head is wrenched back and forth, th creature SAWING ITS WAY THROUGH GUS’S NECK as they fall - then we hear Gus’s neck SNAP as they hit the ice, and he rendered nothing but prey --
A little neon oasis in the snowfall --
(WHISPERS )
No whiskey? No rum?
LUCY IKOS, sturdy, late 60s, stares uncertainly at the te Stranger sitting at her diner counter. The Stranger WILL

head_text.subj: EVER SPEAK IN A SIBILANT, SLIMY WHISPER --

text: Alcohol’s illegal this month -- folks have a hard enough time in the dark without booze making it worse --
Forget the liquor, Lucy. Bring me a bowl of raw hamburger.
You can only get meat two ways around here -- frozen and burnt.  17.
You don’t give me what I want to eat. What I want to drink. He runs a nail across her cheek threateningly. Eben claps hand on the Stranger’s shoulder --
That’s enough, pal. Leave the woman be, time to hit the road. The Stranger rises, out to intimidate -- he’s a bit talle than Eben, but Eben stands his ground without a flinch --
What’s wrong with a man wanting a little fresh meat?
If you refuse to leave, I’1ll escort you out of here myself.
(looms over Eben) I'd like to see that. A GUN BARREL presses against the back of the Stranger’s h STELLA IS HERE, with Billy behind her, as she pulls back hammer on her weapon --

I would too -- but then Lucy’d have to clean up after Eben kicked your ass, it’s more trouble than you’re worth. As Eben takes out cuffs for the Stranger, he takes in Ste presence -- too cool to react, but his energy noticeably different as he looks to Stella’s gun with a raised eyebr
Fire marshal’s office lets you carry that? Stella's also different being around Eben, but she knows best defense is a good offense --
Funny thing, I never asked them. Eben grins to himself as he cuffs the Stranger; it’s clea respects how tough Stella is. He looks to Billy --  18.
My deputy could’ve helped me here --
(an affable shrug) Yeah, but, well, Eben, it’s Stella. Eben nods; Billy has a point. He tries to keep things diplomatic with Stella --
Missed your plane? That sucks. Where are you gonna stay?
Billy and Peggy are putting me up.

(that sucks, too) Well. Talk to you sometime, I guess. It’s awkward, and luckily for Eben, he’s got work to do. Stella shoots a look at Billy that maybe she’1ll leave hi here, then looks to Eben as he leads the cuffed Stranger

Maybe I’11 come along -- say hi to * Jake and Helen -- ? Eben’s got mixed feelings about it, can’t figure out a re to say yes, can’t figure out a reason to say no -- 25A INT. EBEN’S 4X4 - NIGHT 25A Eben drives while Stella rides shotgun, with the Stranger cuffed and seething in the back. They are silent for seve moments, neither of them ready for small talk. Finally --
-- suddenly there’s more vandalism here than in the last three years -- Silence. Finally --

Don’t you know how to take care of this town without me? It’s one of those jokes that hit so wrong; Eben’s answer take a day and a half. Finally Stella gets to why she rea came along --  26 19. STELLA (cont'd) Look, I didn’t want to mention it in public, but I think somebody screwed with the brakes on the ditch driller -- Silence. Finally --
Hell of a day.

Just wait. Eben silences the Stranger with a glare, shoots a glance Stella: let’s not talk now, for God’s sake. INT. SHERIFF’S STATION - NIGHT 26 CELL BARS SLAM in the Stranger’s face as Eben locks him u questions him, Jake watching warily in the b.g.

You don’t work at the refinery. You'd have been seen flying in. When’d you get here? (off his silence) We’ve got all night -- The Stranger smirks, raising an eyebrow: do they? Suddenl Helen bangs at her monitor --
Oh, criminy! Computer’s down.
I’1l call Gus -- (lifting the phone) Phone’s dead, too. Eben SLAMS the receiver down in frustration as the Strang
Mr. and Mrs. Sheriff. So sweet. So helpless against what’s coming. Jake pulls into a corner, freaked out. Stella reassures h
He’s just trying to get our blood up.
It’s working.  27 28 29 20.
We’ve got better things to worry about. I’11 check on Gus.
Check on Gus. Board the windows. Try to hide. They’re coming and this time they’1l take me with them, honor me for all I’ve done -- !

Who are “they?” The Stranger stares steadily at Eben, not giving an inch. Jake tries to focus on his game. BEHIND HIM, THROUGH THE WINDOW, A DEAD-WHITE FACE APPEARS FOR A FLASH. THEN IT’S GONE, just as Jake turns, sensing it -- LIGHTS BLACK OUT -- throwing the room into darkness. The Stranger WHISPERS again, surer and surer of himself --
Board the windows -- try to hide -- EXT. STREETS —- NIGHT 27 Amidst the snowfall, the twinkling streetlights BLINK OUT
INT. SHERIFF’S STATION - NIGHT - RESUME 29
Jake opens the front door in the darkness, ready to head
I’‘1ll hit the generator -- Eben nods, ransacks a drawer in Helen’s desk --
Take a flash -- here --
I'll get them -- But before Helen can intercede, Eben lifts up a flashligh shines it on a plastic bag filled with pot. He’s baffled
What the hell is this?  30 21.
(off Helen) Pot. It helps with her cancer. She’s got a little greenhouse at home.
(lightly) Didn’t tell you, didn’t want you to have to arrest me. Eben shakes his head, perplexed, hands a second flash to Stella as he looks back to Jake --
Now I get why you moved into Helen’s spare room --
(protests too much) Noooo, I just thought you and Stella oughta have privacy --
Yeah, that’s worked out real well. I’m heading for the cell tower.
(off the Stranger’s grin) We have to stay here with him?

(a good pal for Jake) Sure, we can sit here and mock him. Jake beams appreciatively -- we can see he’s glad to have Stella back around. Eben notes it, too, but he’s too focu on his yellow alert to respond --
Helen, as soon as the lines are up, get Billy over here. Stay on the walkie-talkie with me till the power’s back -- Helen nods, as the Stranger grins in expectation --

Snowfall. Eben emerges warily from the 4x4, flashlight an pistol ready. He rounds a corner and stops, pale -- The chain-link fence is down, twisted and bent in the sno Eben pulls his weapon, tensing --
+e

Silence. He presses forward, seeing the satellite dish pu down, broken -- the antennas bent and snapped, WIRES SPAR EBEN (cont'd) What the hell -- ? Eben continues to search. His flashlight finds a trail of FROZEN BLOOD in the snow, red and glossy. Following the trail, Eben finds GUS LAMBERT’S BODY, decapitated and twi in a tangle of wires and bent steel.

head_text.subj: CONTINUING THE SWEEP WITH HIS FLASHLIGHT

text: STUCK IN THE ICE -- ATOP WHICH SITS GUS’S HEAD, WIDE-EYED PAINFUL DEATH. Fighting not to vomit, Eben shines the flash everywhere, he is alone. His breath is heavy, AUDIBLE in the ominous silence. He CLICKS his walkie-talkie -- EBEN (cont'd) Come in, come in, Helen --
(ON WALKIE-TALKIE)
Roger, Eben. What happened there?
(mind racing) We’re being cut off. EXT. STREETS/EBEN’S 4X4 - NIGHT 31 Snowfall. As he drives, Eben’s voice BLASTS OVER A SPEAKE

-- Sheriff Eben Oleson! This is not a drill! Stay in your homes! Lock your doors! Load your firearms! I repeat, Barrow is under curfew -- ! He slows as the 4x4 is approached by a small clutch of wo residents -- the Jayko twins and the ROBBINS FAMILY -- FR MICHELLE, teenage LARRY and seven-year-old GAIL. Eben rol down his window, working for a voice of solid and calm authority even as his own pulse is racing -- EBEN (cont'd) Frank, Michelle, you got your generator running? (off their nod) (MORE )

32Cc 33 23. EBEN (cont‘d) Tell anyone without a jenny, meet at the Diner, stay with Lucy, she’1ll have * heat and power there. Don’t anyone * wander off alone. Get inside, don’t let in anyone you don’t know. And if you've got guns -- load ‘em.
John Riis, mourning, powers up his home generator as he h
Lock your doors! Load your firearms -- EBEN’S VOICE FADES AWAY, lights FLICKER TO LIFE as John p out his shotgun --
Ally calls to the next room, lighting candles for suppert
Let’s have dinner, John -- please? It‘’ll take our minds off -- She sits, closes her eyes a moment, still hurt by the los her dogs. Then she opens her eyes, resolving to move ahea
HURTLES INTO THE ROOM, hidden for a moment behind the tab Ally freezes in panic: what the hell is she alone with --
Hearing the SMASH, John takes his gun and runs to Ally --
-- seeing Ally SCREAMING, PULLED OUT THROUGH THE WINDOW -

He aims for Eben’s face - Eben sees it just in time -- slugs Riis in the stomach -- He pulls away, slipping on ice, losing his gun in deep sn Riis falls, dazed -- but driven by inexplicable hunger, h limps after Eben, who charges off searching for cover --

Eben charges through Riis’s backyard -- but one snowdrift deeper than he expects, and he loses his balance, reachin to the chains on a child’s swingset to right himself -- Riis lunges for Eben, the two tangled in the chains, unab escape each other. Reese’s jaws strain to reach Eben -- Eben pulls out his pistol, but Riis pries it from Eben’s grasp, dropping it so it disappears in the snow --
What the hell happened to you -- ? Riis blinks his eyes; he truly doesn’t know what happened him. Eben searches about in panic, his BREATH GROWING RAS AND RASPIER, finally seeing --

head_text.subj: A PILE OF FIREWOOD ON THE SIDE OF THE HOUSE

text: Eben strains the chains of the swing -- it’1ll mean letti of Riis for a moment, but he dives to reach the axe -- Riis, free now, yearns toward Eben, jaws salivating, abou clamp his teeth down on Eben’s neck -- Eben swings the axe hard, CATCHING Riis in the shoulder -  48.
(in pain but still going)

Black blood flows from Riis’s wound as Eben wriggles loos gets his bearings and then SWINGS AGAIN AND AGAIN -- focu on Eben’s pain as he’s forced to do what must be done -- Finally he staggers back against the woodpile, groping fo inhaler, GIVING HIMSELF A BLAST. But it’s the last blast Eben tosses the now-useless inhaler into the snow. He’s n sure how he’1ll make it without the inhaler, but for now no choice. PAN from Eben toward the swingset, where a headless corpse hangs, caught up in the chains of the swi
Stella and Beau meet a drained Eben sweeping his tracks. pull the board closed as Eben joins them inside with his
-- lost my gun --
-- wouldn’ta done any good anyway --

-- think there’s close to twenty of them, but there might as well be two hundred -- they’re watching everywhere, don’t know what they’re planning -- (the worst revelation) -- and John became one of them. Stella and Beau try to absorb this -- it can’t be true --
How’d you stop him? Eben nods grimly toward his bloodied axe --
Nothing lives without a head. Stella watches Eben wrestling with what he’s done --
You had to.
I may have to again -- they can turn us into them --

Oh God -- Stella and Eben wrestle with the shock -- the world is so more horrible than they ever dreamed -- as Beau examines bloodied axe soberly, eyes full of dread. Stella looks to attic with a sudden apprehension -- STELLA (cont'd) If we tell everyone, they’1ll panic --
People deserve to know.
And if they don’t know, they could get us killed -- they gotta get what’s at stake --
(still not sure) How do we tell them?
(a beat) How do we not?
Marlow and Iris grimly examine Riis’s corpse, Marlow fing Riis’s fangs with his talon-like nails. He looks to Iris, curious -- THEY did not do this. Who could have?
TITLE: DAY 12. Jake scoops the last from a can of Deviled Ham, looks to Stella --
You sure you don’t want the last? (Stella shakes her head) I used to like the little devil on these cans.
If we can last till daylight’s back -- they didn’t show up till sundown. Maybe they can’t stand the light. It’s only two and a half weeks --  50.
(a helpless laugh) Yeah, that’s all.
We can’t hold out without food -- !
What about other houses? People might’ve left something.

They could be hiding and living on it themselves. There were 152 folks in town. Billy and his family, Paul Jayko, the Robbinses, Adam and Jeannie: we’re not the only ones left. The others look toward the outside, considering, as Eben them a crude map he’s drawn on the back of a traffic tick EBEN (cont'd) Look. Before too long there'll be a blizzard. And when it happens, we just need to walk. (indicating on the map) Each lot in town’s twenty-five feet wide. So the general store’s two hundred seventy-five feet east. The Utilidor’s seventy-five west, then due north as far as you can go. We can hit the store for food and then burrow down in the Utilidor. (as the others absorb it) We know this town. We can walk it blindfolded. We just have to wait for the weather we’ve lived with since we were born. The survivors stir with hope; even Doug takes a breath an finds a bit of patience. Stella turns privately toward Eb taking him aside --
Hey. You know how you told me you could never be a dad? Bullshit. The way you look out for these people --
Don’t compliment me, you’1l just confuse me.
It’s not a compliment. It’s an attempt to ram something through that concrete skull: you can pull off more than you think you can.
(a beat) Not if I have to worry my wife’1l run away when we can’t work something out. They glare at each other in frustration -- not sure why e conversation between them has to end in a quarrel --
TITLE: DAY 14. CLOSE on Isaac’s rheumy, eager eyes --

Isaac has lowered the ladder, he’s walking downstairs -- Stella follows him with her flashlight, WHISPERING URGENT Unlike everyone else who must not speak above a hiss, Isa speaks in his normal full voice, calm and determined --
I’m walking to Wainwright --
It’s eighty miles, there’s no way to get there. Come back upstairs -- Wilson descends the staircase, alarmed --
Wilson! Come along, we need to get out! Bring your mother, too -- Stella holds onto Isaac before he can reach the front doo works to shake her off.
We'll die if you go out there -- !

(angry now) NO. NO. I’LL DIE IF I STAY IN HERE -- Stella clamps a hand over Isaac’s mouth. Stella and Wilso struggle to hold Isaac back -- he wriggles and writhes un finally he CRIES, and stops resisting --  52. ISAAC (cont'd) (WHISPERING AT LAST)
I’m sorry -- Jesus, look at me -- I’m so sorry --
(lost for words) It’s all right, Dad -- anyone would --
Just stay quiet, Mr. Bulosan --
(looks around, confused) Can I -- the bathroom -- ?

Remember you can’t flush, the noise -- we'll just open the valve afterward -- Isaac nods, not understanding fully but cooperating for n They lead him delicately to the bathroom and Wilson close door on his father -- then slides down the wall, drained. Stella tries to encourage him -- STELLA (cont'd) What are the odds we would make it this long? We’re ahead of the curve.
Every day they need more food. They’1l be back.
Maybe they’1l starve first. Ever think of that? We can see in the empty houses, they’re not rifling through pantries, they’re not living on frozen food --

We‘re their frozen food -- Suddenly, a SLIDING RASP from inside the bathroom. They l to each other in alarm. Wilson TAPS on the door -- WILSON (cont’d) Dad? (silence) Dad -- ?! (rising, to Stella) Should we break in?  82 83 53.

The noise. She pulls out her driver’s license, slips it through the to manipulate it open. She shines her flashlight inside - Revealing an empty bathroom -- and an OPEN WINDOW. Wilson turns and runs for the front; Stella catches him - STELLA (cont'd) Wait! You can’t just rush out there!
Wilson tugs loose -- Stella reaches for him again. Withou warning he turns around and SLUGS her flat -- she lands w THUMP as Wilson escapes out the front door --
The THUMP makes Eben’s eyes blink instantly awake --
Stella -- ? He searches the room. Only Doug and Lucy are awake. Lucy points down the ladder. Eben bolts up, disoriented and alarmed, and reaches for his axe --
Eben descends the ladder warily, axe ready -- only to fin Stella dazed on the floor where she fell --
What the hell happened?
I’m fine, thanks -- He knows that, but he’s too alarmed at the signs of dange say anything of comfort --
How long has this ladder been down?
(getting her bearings) Oh God -- maybe five minutes -- Eben lifts the ladder back into place, as Stella rises --  84 85 54. STELLA (cont'd) Isaac took off for Wainwright. Wilson went to find him --
And you let them go? Stella rubs her jaw; archly --
Yeah, that’s just what I did.
Wilson moves quickly, risking death every second he’s out in the attic he was only wearing a down vest, unprepared the savagery of the cold --

(hissing) Dad! Dad -- ! Silence. SNOW BEGINS TO FALL, WIND GROWS. Wilson looks to the sky, down an alley, under a house, growing desperate The loose door of a house SLAMS in the wind -- Wilson startles, backing away from the house -- Shivering, teeth starting to chatter, he’s realizing this very BAD idea, but he can’t abandon his father -- WILSON (cont'd) Daaaad -- ! His breath billows -- he wipes snow and tears from his fa steps into a small snowbank -- and is suddenly PULLED THE
He starts to GASP -- when his cries are MUFFLED IN THE SN Second by second, the snowbank turns RED WITH HIS BLOOD.
Eben and Stella simmer, bitter with losing Wilson --
You should’ve stopped him.
I fucking tried.  86 55.
Oh yeah? How hard? Part of you probably thought: of course he should look for his dad, right?
(a beat; stung) At least Wilson went out doing what he had to, for his family -- Eben can’t believe she’s throwing this at him now -- ters he returns the favor --

Or he was just screwed because someone ran out on him. Eben and Stella stare each other down -- too angry to kno to work through this until -- AN EERIE SCRATCHING SUDDENLY FILLS THE ROOM ABOVE. Eben and Stella scramble upstairs and pull the ladder clo

THEN IT DOUBLES AND TRIPLES, AS IF THERE ARE THREE CREATU

text: Eben tenses, his breathing tight and thin. Stella and Jak look to him in concern --  56. After an achingly fearful moment, the eye disappears, the SCRABBLING SOUNDS STOP. Eben looks to the others, his voice tight with congestion alarm -- clearly the Kelso house is compromised now -- EBEN (cont'd) It’s snowing -- grab trashbags from * downstairs, we’re getting all the food * we can carry -- * But his breathing is also compromised -- Eben’s chest hea sucking in air. Stella approaches, sotto voce:
Your inhaler --
(not sure he heard that) What -- ?
(between breaths) Useless -- threw it in the snow --

What’re you going to do Wait a minute wait a minute, * without an inhaler? Do they what? You’ve got, like, some have them in the store -- ? kinda breathing problem? * Eben nods tersely to both of them, fighting for breath, a Doug reappraises Eben in a panic -- DOUG (cont'd) We’re following your plans, and you're * keeping secrets? What else don’t we * know -- ? *
(had enough of this) -- shut up, Doug --

Fuck no! YOU shut up! Furious, Doug SHOVES Eben back -- and even through his pa breaths, Eben BACKHANDS Doug into the wall. Stella interc as Eben braces himself against Jake, pulling in air --  87 88 57.
Jesus, Doug!
(over, re Eben) He’s right, we need food -- ! Doug’s about to speak again, when Jake SLAMS him to the f

What the hell?! When the shit went down, who kept it together? You were busy shouting, “They can’t be shot!” Who kept it together?! They both know the answer. They look to Eben, who’s final recovering his breath bit by bit. Raspily Eben settles it
-- we need to move --
TITLE: DAY 15. Snow falls harder and harder on Barrow. A

A modest home. Adam Colletta and his wife JEANNIE, 30s, l on the living room floor, wrenched from their hiding plac Adam, a newly-fired pistol in his hand, stares in amazeme Marlow, BLOOD DRIPPING FROM HIS CHEST, glares at them whi ripping the gun from Adam’s hands. He speaks in a GUTTERA RASP -- his English not easy, his accent unplaceable --

You had your chance to help us find your friends. Now, you'll have to watch. Marlow lifts up Adam, reaches for a fireplace poker, and IMPALES Adam through the guts and into the wall. Choking pain, Adam is unable to move as Marlow takes Adam’s chin directs his gaze toward Iris -- MARLOW (cont'd) Iris. You may take your time. Neither Marlow nor Iris takes any sadistic pleasure from it’s simply the price that Adam and Jeannie must pay for resistance. Iris reaches for a hand of the terrified, sob Jeannie -- WE HEAR HIS FINGERS SNAPPING ONE AT A TIME --  89 58.

Marlow, not as distracted by this as he wishes he could b drops his hold on Adam, wanders to the stereo system. As Jeannie GASPS in the b.g. with each finger SNAPPED, Marlo rests a talon on a phonograph record sitting on the turnt It’s almost as if, through his talons, he listens to the in the record grooves, his thoughts alive but unreadable
Everyone is thinner, dirtier, drained. Eben faces them, energized for a plan, a plan not everyone trusts yet --
-- the fastest of us head to the store for food and supplies -- then if the storm’s still holding out, we all go to the Utilidor.
(quiet, surly) You really think we can make it?
You can’t see a foot out there. So neither can they. The whiteout will cover our tracks -- if we leave now.
And how do we get into the Utilidor? It’s locked tight -- hell if I know where my keys are -- Eben and Stella trade looks -- wheels turning --
That sewage pipe. The one the twins were fixing -- ?
(thinking it through) It’s shut off from the rest of the town. It’1ll lead straight underground and inside.
(wincing at the idea) The sewage pipe.
It hasn't been used in weeks. Be glad you'll be alive to smell it. And once we're out there -- NO STOPPING. There’s no fighting these things, we have to move move move --

Whiteout. HOWLING WIND. Scarved and masked, Eben carries axe as he leads the survivors step by step through the bi snow, as SCREECHES ECHO DISTANTLY around them. Lucy stumb Carter helps her as they fight to clear their vision. Thr the chaos, we hear Eben’s BREATH, SHALLOW AND TENSE --
Whiteout. Marlow (chest now wrapped in clothes from Adam Colletta) stands with Iris, peering through the sheets of

Whiteout. Eben and his crew feel their way up the steps o the general store. Lucy practically sobs with relief as Carter helps her in. The doorway looms like a black hole snow collecting in the open threshold --

Stella runs her flashlight over the store as Eben’s ready swing his axe -- all appears clear. The survivors pull plastic trashbags from their parkas, as Eben looks first Beau, Lucy, Denise and Doug --
You four, grab all the canned goods you can. Stella and Carter, propane and batteries. Jake, medical supplies. I’m getting axes and bear traps. You have two minutes.

Jake stuffs his bag with pain meds and bandages. Eben pas him and grabs a handful of INHALERS. Eben pops one open, shakes it, BLASTS HIMSELF GRATEFULLY, shoves the inhalers pocket and moves on with a new energy --  99 100-102 103 104 60.
Eben pulls three bear traps, tucks them under one arm, th reaches for axes. Down the aisle, Stella and Carter bundl more propane canisters and batteries --
Denise, Beau and Lucy collect cases of Ensure. Doug additionally stuffs his pockets with Oreos, grimly chuckl
Told my wife I wouldn’t live on these while she was gone --
She’1l cut you slack. As they wad their trashbags full of emergency nutrition, hear a quiet SOBBING coming from the back. The four of th exchange looks, and warily walk toward --
Where they see, from behind, the source of the SOBBING -- LITTLE GIRL, bent over the prone, bloodied body of Tom Melanson, the kid we met kissing his girlfriend farewell

It’s Tommy Melanson -- (to the girl) Oh, honey, you need to come with -- The girl turns and looks at them. Her mouth is covered in blood, and we see now that it’s Tom Melanson who’s doing sobbing -- the girl is a vampire --

I’m done playing with this one -- She places a taloned hand on Tom’s jaw and RIPS as she ey them eerily -- LITTLE GIRL (cont'd) You want to play with me now? The four onlookers freak -- Beau reaches for a shovel to as a weapon, while the others charge back into the store  105 61.
Denise hisses in a panic toward Eben and Stella --

In the back -- !! Beau’s tossed violently back into the store like a toy, t shovel clattering uselessly behind him. Eben drops his beartraps, brandishes an axe, ready to swing -- But the little girl careens out of the storage room like dervish, presenting a smaller target than Eben expected - swings over her head and she knocks him down -- The little girl’s about to pounce on Eben when Stella gra her from behind and THROWS HER AWAY DOWN THE AISLE -- Doug pulls Denise toward the front, as Carter reaches for can of MACE and sprays it into the little girl’s face -- IT SHRIEKS and only lunges for Carter all the harder, rip off his cap and baring her fangs -- But now Eben’s back -- he charges the girl and fights to her against the wall -- she kicks and spits like a snake Eben looks for help -- Beau and Stella join him to pin th girl as she nearly wriggles from their grip -- they can’t her long --
The axe -- somebody -- !
Doug keeps pulling Denise and Lucy toward the door --
Come on -- ! The women waver, not sure if they should run out yet --
The little girl kicks and twists -- Eben, Beau and Stella losing their grip on her as Carter reels in pain in the b

And an axeblade FLASHES past Eben’s face --  62. Suddenly the little girl’s body is still -- writhing only automatic nervous movement for a few moments. Eben, Stell and Beau look up to see -- Jake -- axe in hand -- falling backward against the dry g knocked for a loop by what he’s done, fighting tears -- Eben embraces his brother in concern -- then looks to Dou Lucy and Denise as they slowly emerge -- EBEN (cont'd) Where the hell were you?!
(a beat) I thought we should get the food back to the others -- in case you lost. Eben rises in pain, catching his breath as he considers D plan -- then ruefully claps Doug on the shoulder --
Smart call. Jake stands over the corpse, still overwhelmed --
She -- just a girl --
(consoling him) Not anymore.
She spoke to us. In English. Was she some girl they just turned -- or one of them? Does anybody recognize her?

(correcting Denise) It. Not her. They look toward the decapitated head, wincing. Nobody ha answer. Lucy walks toward the front door, reeling. Carter (scarf tightly wrapped around his head) sounds nauseated
It pulled Tom’s head off before it attacked us --
Maybe they don’t just do that out of bloodthirst --  106-107 108 109 110 63.
(agreeing) They want to keep their numbers down. They don’t want to give themselves competition. Eben and Stella share a look: no enemy has ever been more ruthless --
(from the doorway) The whiteout’s over --
Eben and Stella appear in the doorway in panic toward the front -- to see it’s true. The snow has eased to the poin where the street is visible again through the front door
Our cover’s gone.
And the fresh snow’ll show tracks. They regard each other in dread --
Lighter snowfall. Marlow and Iris stand and shake the sno from their shoulders, ready to hunt again -- Across the street, they see two other vampires climbing a the eaves of houses, also starving --
The survivors huddle in the back, trapped, brainstorming
They watch the store more than anyplace else. We need to move or we'll be trapped.
We can’t get to the Utilidor. It’s too far without cover.
Could we make it back to your station if somebody created a diversion?  64. Eben studies his old friend, hearing how Carter’s offerin himself for that role --
It’s not going to be you, Carter -- Eben and Carter face off, respecting each other’s bravery when Stella speaks up with the energy of a new plan --
It won’t be you either. These things can’t survive the sun. What if we brought the sun early?
Like exactly?
Helen had that medical marijuana operation at home --
(getting it) Yeah -- she used an ultraviolet lamp to grow the stuff --
(desperate humor) All right, Helen!
I can run for her place -- let them follow me -- then fry them with the sunlamp while the rest of you beat it to the sheriff’s station.
What the hell makes you think a sunlamp will make a dent in them?
(overlapping) We’ve got all kinds of wattage at the Utilidor and they still came and ate Xavier Jayko --
Ultraviolet, Carter. There’s no UV light here for another two weeks. It'll be the last thing they expect.
Just because something stopped Bela Lugosi doesn’t mean it’ll stop these things.
They didn’t show up till it was dark. Why would they use that stranger to cut us off -- unless they just can’t handle sunlight?
What if it doesn’t work -- ?
(she’s got nothing) It has to. (a deep breath) Take this, I need to run light -- She tries to hand Eben the propane, but he shakes his hea
I can run fastest.
Bullshit. I weigh less than you, I don’t have asthma --
(suddenly harsh)
(re the asthma) What, everybody knows now -- !
You're fifteen. Forget it.
I’m fifteen, right. You’ve got a wife, people need you --

(into Jake’s face) I saw you when you killed that girl. Crying little boy. You try and tell me you’re up to doing that three or four more times. What do you say?! It’s harsh, but Eben has to be harsh to keep Jake here. Jake’s stunned silent;  111 112 113 114 66. he can’t help resenting how right Eben is. Stella glances Jake, underscoring the idea that Jake had better not push then looks back to Eben --
You don’t even think this plan’1l work.

But you do. Right? She’s silent, realizing Eben trusts her this much -- EBEN (cont'd) Look, who’s the sheriff, and who’s the bureaucrat from Anchorage? I’m making the run. I‘11 stop them with the sunlamp and see you back at the attic. She steels herself, reluctantly handing him the walkie-ta
You’1l need to start her jenny first.
It’s in her sideyard by the woodpile. Head in the back door, the pot’s growing in the laundry room.
(holds Eben to this) See you soon. He turns to go -- she’s loving and hating him for putting himself on the line like this --
Light snowfall, ethereal calm. Until Eben BOLTS out of th store, setting a land speed record as he lets his AXE WHA AGAINST LAMPPOSTS, drawing attention away from the store

Light snowfall. Marlow, Iris and two other vampires HEAR SOUNDS EBEN’S CREATING -- they turn a corner to see Eben speeding away at the end of the next block --  67. 115 EXT. HELEN’S HOUSE - NIGHT 115 Light snowfall. A modest, unassuming home, its front wind broken. Eben, WHEEZING, caroms into the side yard and pus the generator button. Nothing. He pushes it again, again finally it STARTS WHIRRING TO LIFE --
Light snowfall. Marlow’s pack turns in the direction of t
117 INT. HELEN’S HOUSE - NIGHT 117 Eben, breath thicker and thicker, runs into the laundry r finds the pot garden. He BLASTS HIS INHALER as he flips o lightswitch --
THE NOW-DEAD PLANTS -— Eben laughs despite himself, light’s never been so beauti

(hissing) Go, go, go -- ! 119 EXT. HELEN’S HOUSE - NIGHT 119 The snow has stopped. Marlow, Iris and the others reach * Helen’s house, eyes filled with murderous anticipation -- 120 INT. HELEN’S HOUSE - NIGHT 120 Eben readies the sunlamp, steeling himself for confrontat The floor CREAKS -- and Eben freezes. They could come at from any direction. The MOAN of the wind through the hous SLAMS A DOOR open and shut somewhere, keeping him on edge

Stella’s party hustles ahead -- Beau in the lead, Denise, and a bundled-up Carter behind him, followed by Jake and Stella. Doug, in the rear, stumbles in a snowdrift, his s of food spilling everywhere. As he scrabbles in the snow quickly to retrieve it all --  122 123 124 125 68. WHOOOOM -- there is a flash of black -- a vampire drops f the rooftops onto Doug -- He lashes at Doug’s neck, KEENING to call allies as Stell party disappears around a corner ahead -- Stella turns at the KEENING of the vampire, the GURGLING SCREAMS from DOUG -- but Carter pulls her onward. In a co sweat, she knows she must keep the others moving -- EXT. SHERIFF’S STATION - NIGHT 122 The survivors haul inside -- faint lights flickering as t jenny fights on. Beau covers them at the door with his shotgun as Stella copes with her fear for Eben -- INT. HELEN’S HOUSE - NIGHT 123 Eben’s primed for the attack -- but still it’s a shock wh the vampires BREAK DOWN THE DOOR after Eben. He sucks in the breath he can, and aims the sunlamp at them -- IRIS SIZZLES -- her skin charring as she KEENS IN PAIN an staggers away -- Eben holds fast -- this rare victory overwhelming him wit relief, even as his eyes widen in awe at this uncanny sig Marlow pulls Iris away, but LOCKS EYES with Eben for one moment -- nobody has ever destroyed one of his toys. He w not forget Eben -- Marlow backs away with the dying Iris before he can be hi with the next blast of UV light -- INT. SHERIFF’S STATION - NIGHT 124 Jake looks soberly at the floor, where shreds of Helen’s and the Stranger’s clothes lie amid BLOODSTAINS. Stella k the lights, fires up the WALKIE-TALKIE --

Eben, we’re safe -- your status? INT./EXT. HELEN’S HOUSE - NIGHT 125 Eben looks out the window -- outside Iris is collapsing t ground, a CHARRED HUSK. Marlow is VISIBLY ORDERING the ot two attackers to tear the generator loose --
It worked once -- but they’re killing the power -- !
126 69. INT. SHERIFF’S STATION - NIGHT - RESUME 126 Stella, Beau and the other survivors listen in alarm --
(on WALKIE-TALKIE) -- I’ll have to run for it somehow --

(hushed, despite herself) He’s toast -- Forget about their quarrels -- Stella slowly dies inside the knowledge that she’s losing Eben -- Beau’s struck by Stella’s pain -- moved despite himself - grabs the walkie-talkie from Stella, CLICKING IT ON --
I’1l get you a shot, Sheriff. Break out and tear for Rogers Avenue, run toward the ditch driller --
The brakes are jammed on that thing --
What I got in mind don’t need brakes. Beau hefts the bear traps, heads for the ladder, resolved his plan becomes clear to a stunned Stella --
Beau -- ?!! Beau pulls a wad of unpaid tickets from his parka --
Tell Eben to mark these paid in full, okay?
You can’t -- !
Eben’s done his turn as decoy -- (honestly now) -- he’s needed more’n I am -- OFF Stella, both scared and touched -- and as
127 128 129 130 131 132 133 70. INT. HELEN’S HOUSE - NIGHT 127 Eben charges out the front door, while behind the house -
INT. HELEN’S HOUSE - NIGHT - CONTINUOUS 129 Marlow SMASHES the sunlamp as he urges the others after E

Eben darts with his axe from house to house, seeing the s sign for Rogers Avenue -- EXT. HELEN’S HOUSE - NIGHT 131 Marlow SNARLS in pursuit, pointing out Eben’s footprints the others -- HOWLING IN BLOODLUST --

Marlow’s trio is joined by FOUR MORE VAMPIRES answering t howl -- the seven prowl down the avenue in search of Eben They pause when they hear a LOW GRUMBLING ROAR behind the Suddenly an enormous CHAINSAW lunges at Marlow’s crew -- ditch driller. With an impudent Beau at the wheel. The chainsaw’s steel teeth RIPPING through one vampire’s body TORN IN HALF as Beau steers the ditch driller forward --

Who’s next, huh? The vampires swarm toward the ditch driller furiously -- of them jumping into the dump bay to attack Beau from beh SNAP! He lands in a steel BEAR TRAP camouflaged under the snow. The trap’s TEETH rip into his leg -- he bleeds blac upon the snow and falls off the truck -- mauled by the ti chains as Beau drives over him -- EBEN runs to help, outdistanced as Beau drives the ditch driller away with the vampires swarming over it. Eben sta in awe --

Beau sees two vampires swarming onto his hood, bashing at windshield and creating SPIDER-WEB CRACKS THROUGHOUT. He SWERVES AND FISHTAILS -- hurtling the vamps this way and One slips and falls into the CHAINSAW --  134 135 136 137 138 71. Beau FLOORS the gas again --

Welcome to Barrow! Top of the world! INT. SHERIFF’S STATION - NIGHT 134 Stella watches around the edge of a windowblind for Eben While Carter uses a small flashlight to look into a MIRRO His face is scarred -- skin dead-white -- EYES NOW DEAD-B

Beau drives on, as vampires race toward the ditch driller the alleys. He aims his SHOTGUN at them -- pumping rounds LOADING. RELOADING. SHOOTING. Driving back enemies -- -- but the swarm is inevitably starting to engulf him. He circles back onto --
-- and steers toward the ADMIRALTY BAY HOTEL as vampires SHATTER the windshield. Powering straight into the hotel, Beau SCREAMS ALL THE WAY as the ditch driller impacts --

Sudden quiet. The ditch driller sits in the middle of rub Beau grabs his shotgun and a box of FLARES from the truck climbing out through the windshield -- No sign of his enemies. do -- he reaches into his depths and pulls up the ferocit strength of a wildcat -- Reaching up, he takes hold of Marlow’s jaw with his wound hand, and in a berserker rage, SLAMS HIS GOOD HAND ALL TH INTO MARLOW’S MOUTH --— The vampires gape in AWE AT THE SOUND OF RIPPING FLESH -- And MARLOW’S HEAD lands on the ice in a rush of red pain shock, still not realizing he’s lost. -- I sent Billy to take you to the airport -- knew he wouldn’t make it -- wanted you to stay -- A grateful nod from Stella; she always suspected it. She works to contain her fears as he winces, not sure he can endure the pain any longer -- EBEN (cont'd) Baby --
